advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;U.S. ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Most small system users think all microcomputers are created aqual. And they're right. If you want performance, convenience, styling, high technology and reliability (and who doesn't?) your micro usually has a price tag that looks mote like a mini. It seems big performance always means big bucks. But not so with the SuperBrain...</font><

<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;QD VERSION ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>1980 Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Our new QD model has all of the features of our phenomenally popular SuperBrain with the addition of double-sided disk drives and an extra of dynamic RAM. So, for only a modest increase in price, you can order your next SuperBrain with more than twice the disk and memory storage capability. But, best of all, the new QD model has the same tough, rugged construction and exceptional quality that made our SuperBrain such a success. </font> <

<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;COMPUSTAR NETWORK</strong></font><br><blockquote>Compustar is the network version of the SuperBrain. Each SuperBrain computer became an 'intelligent' video terminal called a Video Processing Unit and containing its own microprocessor and 64 KB of RAM. Single or double floppy disc could be added for 350 KB to 1.5 MB local storage. Up to 255 terminals could be connected into the same network. Maximum cable length between two terminal was one mile at a 1.6 MB data transfer rate. Each of them could share a disk storage system, from 10 to 96 MB with CP/M operating system. <

<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;SUPERBRAIN II ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>SuperBrain II's internal circuitry has been completely redesigned. There were four models availables, from 350 KB to 10 MB of storage capacity.<br><br> The new version offered a faster enhanced disk operating system, new video visual attributes ans better graphics capabilities. <br><br> Prices started at $2,495<

<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;THE PERSONABLE COMPUTER</strong></font><br><blockquote>January 1983<br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> What's a personable computer? It's a computer with business application versatility at personal computer price. It's a computer powerful enough to tackle even your toughest business jobs, yet at a price that wont put you out of business...</font><

<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;COMPUSTAR AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Compustar standard features in 1983:<br> - 350 KB / 750 KB / 1.5 MB workstation disk capacities<br> - 10 to 144 MB storage options<br><br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Compustar is built and backed by the company that's been in the microcomputer business as long as microcomputers have been in business. Would you trust your business to anything less?</font> <

<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;CMC INTERNATIONAL</strong></font><br><blockquote>It seems that the CMC Company (We have no more info about this company) used SuperBrain systems in which they added various hard disks, from 5 to 20 MB. <

computer.description:
The Superbrain was an integrated system with keyboard, display and disc drives. The system used two Z80A microprocessors at 4 MHz, one for the main processing, and the other for peripheral activities.
The dual 5" floppy disc units could be 2x170 KB (single side), 2x340 KB (DS), and a 10 MB CompuStar hard disk could be added.
The SuperBrain was sold with the CP/M operating system, Microsoft Basic, an 8080 assembler and Microsoft Cobol 74.
The SuperBrain II appeared in 1982. It offered a faster and enhanced disk operating system, new video visual attributes and better graphics capabilities. _______________________
computer.name: SUPERBRAIN
computer.price: 2 x 175 KB: about $4200 2 x 350 KB: about $5000
